information.title: Definition
information.description: The Preamble is an introductory statement in the Constitution of India, stating the guiding purpose and principles of the document.

information.title: Key Words
information.description: The Preamble declares India to be a Sovereign, Socialist, Secular, Democratic Republic. It also promises justice, liberty, equality, and fraternity to all citizens.

information.title: We, the People
information.description: The Preamble begins with 'We, the People of India', emphasizing that the Constitution derives its authority from the people of India.

information.title: Date of Adoption
information.description: The Preamble states that the people of India adopted and enacted the Constitution on 26th November 1949.

information.title: Amendments
information.description: The Preamble has been amended once by the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976, which added the words 'Socialist', 'Secular', and 'Integrity' to the original version.
